audio.def: The process of taking up or assimilating a substance.
Coordinated changes in the lens of the eye that enable one to focus on near and far objects.
(ACh) Neurotransmitter; released at synapses within the nervous system and at the neuromuscular junction.
Substance that can release a hydrogen ion when dissolved in water.
One of the two contractile proteins in muscle cells, the other being myosin.
Rapid depolarization and repolarization of the plasma membrane capable of spreading down the neuron or muscle membrane; nerve impulse.

Movement of molecules into or out of a cell from an area where they are in lower concentration to an area where they are in higher concentration. Such movement, which is opposite to the direction of normal flow by diffusion, requires energy and transporters.
Popular name for pharyngeal tonsil located in the nasopharynx.
Referring to fats or a type of connective tissue that stores fat.
Carrying toward a given point, such as a sensory neuron that carries nerve impulses toward the central nervous system.
Clumping of cells due to an antigen–antibody reaction.
Muscle that contracts to perform a given movement.
Protein in blood plasma and other body fluids; helps maintain the osmotic pressure of the blood.
A version of a gene that controls a given trait.
Small sac or pouch; usually a tiny air sac in the lungs through which gases are exchanged between the outside air and the blood; tooth socket; pl., alveoli.
acid Building block of protein.
sac Fluid-filled sac that surrounds and cushions the developing fetus.
Slightly movable joint.
Metabolic building of simple compounds into more complex substances needed by the body.
Standard position of the body for anatomic studies or designations, upright, face front, arms at side with palms forward, and feet parallel.
Study of body structure.
Radiography of vessels following injection of a contrast material.

Substance produced from inactive precursors by the action of the renal enzyme renin and other enzymes; increases blood pressure by causing vascular constriction, stimulating the release of aldosterone from the adrenal cortex and ADH from the posterior pituitary, and increasing thirst.
Negatively charged particle (ion).
Muscle that has an action opposite that of a given movement or muscle; substance that opposes the action of another substance.
(Ab) Substance produced in response to a specific antigen; immunoglobulin.
hormone (ADH) Hormone released from the posterior pituitary gland that increases water reabsorption in the kidneys, thus decreasing the urinary output.
(Ag) Substance that induces an immune response.
Serum containing antibodies that may be given to provide passive immunity; immune serum.
Antibody that neutralizes a toxin.
The largest artery; carries blood out of the heart’s left ventricle.
Referring to a gland that releases some cellular material along with its secretions.
humor Watery fluid that fills much of the eyeball anterior to the lens.
Pertaining to water; an aqueous solution is one in which water is the solvent.
Referring to loose connective tissue, any small space, or to an areola, a circular area of marked color.
Muscle attached to a hair follicle that raises the hair.
Loss or abnormality of rhythm, usually of the heart; dysrhythmia.
Vessel between a small artery and a capillary.
Vessel that carries blood away from the heart.
A joint; an area of junction or union between two or more structures.
Smallest subunit of a chemical element.
One of the heart’s two upper chambers; adj., atrial.
Weakened.
tube Tube that connects the middle ear cavity to the throat; eustachian tube.
nervous system (ANS) The part of the nervous system that controls smooth muscle, cardiac muscle, and glands; the visceral or involuntary nervous system.
Any chromosome not involved in sex determination. There are 44 autosomes (22 pairs) in humans.
Fiber of a neuron that conducts impulses away from the cell body.
Agranular white blood cell that gives rise to antibody-producing plasma cells in response to an antigen; B lymphocyte.
Receptor that responds to pressure, such as those in vessel walls that respond to stretching and help regulate blood pressure; a type of mechanoreceptor.
metabolism The amount of energy needed to maintain life functions while the body is at rest.
Interconnected masses of gray matter spread throughout the brain that modulate motor inputs and facilitate routine motor tasks; basal ganglia.

td.font: A lower portion or foundation. Substance that can accept a hydrogen ion (H+); substance that releases a hydroxide ion (OH−) when dissolved in water; an alkali. The broad, superior portion of the heart.

audio.def: Granular white blood cell that shows large, dark blue cytoplasmic granules when stained with basic stain.
Molecule that combines with hydrogen ion to form carbonic acid, which separates into carbon dioxide and water; an important buffer in body fluids.
Substance produced in the liver that emulsifies fats.
Heart rate of less than 60 beats per minute.
Portion of the brain that connects the cerebrum with the spinal cord; contains the midbrain, pons, and medulla oblongata.
Microscopic branch of a bronchus.
Large air passageway in the lung; pl., bronchi (BRONG-ki).
Substance that prevents sharp changes in a solution’s pH.
Small, fluid-filled sac found in an area subject to stress around bones and joints; pl., bursae (BER-se).
Microscopic vessel through which exchanges take place between the blood and the tissues.
Simple sugar or compound made from simple sugars linked together, such as starch or glycogen.
Acid formed when carbon dioxide dissolves in water; carbonic acid then separates into hydrogen ion and bicarbonate ion.
Enzyme that catalyzes the interconversion of carbon dioxide with bicarbonate ion and hydrogen ion.
output (CO) Volume of blood pumped by each ventricle in one minute. CO is the product of stroke volume and heart rate.
Individual who has a recessive allele of a gene that is not expressed in the phenotype but that can be passed to offspring.
Type of hard connective tissue found at the ends of bones, the tip of the nose, larynx, trachea, and the embryonic skeleton.
Metabolic breakdown of substances into simpler substances; includes the digestion of food and the oxidation of nutrient molecules for energy.
Substance that speeds the rate of a chemical reaction.
Positively charged particle (ion).
Basic unit of life.
Series of reactions by which nutrients are oxidized for energy within the mitochondria of body cells.
An instrument that separates materials in a mixture based on density.
Small section of the brain inferior to the cerebral hemispheres; functions in coordination, balance, and muscle tone.
cortex Very thin outer layer of gray matter on the surface of the cerebral hemispheres.
fluid (CSF) Fluid that circulates in and around the brain and spinal cord.
Largest part of the brain; composed of two cerebral hemispheres.
Earwax; adj., ceruminous (seh-RU-min-us).
Study of the composition and properties of matter.
Receptor that responds to chemicals in body fluids.
Cell that produces and maintains cartilage.
Outer embryonic layer that, together with a layer of the endometrium, forms the placenta.
Pigmented middle layer of the eye.
Dark-staining, threadlike body in a cell’s nucleus; contains genes that determine hereditary traits.
Milky-appearing fluid absorbed into the lymphatic system from the small intestine. It consists of lymph and droplets of digested fat.
Mixture of partially digested food, water, and digestive juices that forms in the stomach.
Circular movement at a joint.
Clotting, as of blood.
Coiled portion of the inner ear that contains the organ of hearing.
Flexible white protein that gives strength and resilience to connective tissue, such as bone and cartilage.
Mixture in which suspended particles do not dissolve but remain distributed in the solvent because of their small size (e.g., cytoplasm); colloidal suspension.
Secretion of the mammary glands released prior to secretion of milk.
Group of blood proteins that helps antibodies and phagocytes to destroy foreign cells.
Ease with which a hollow structure, such as the thorax or alveoli of the lungs, can be expanded under pressure.
Substance composed of two or more chemical elements.
Membrane that lines the eyelid and covers the anterior part of the sclera (white of the eye).
Capacity to undergo shortening, as in muscle tissue.
Centering of both eyes on the same visual field.
Clear portion of the sclera that covers the anterior of the eye.
Referring to the heart or to the arteries supplying blood to the heart.
Thick bundle of myelinated nerve cell fibers deep within the brain that carries nerve impulses from one cerebral hemisphere to the other.
Yellow body formed from ovarian follicle after ovulation; produces estrogen and progesterone.
Sediment formed when plasma is frozen and thawed. It is rich in fibrinogen and clotting factors.
Peptide produced by immune cells or other cells that acts as a cellular signal; (e.g., interleukin).
Study of cells.
Substance that fills the cell, consisting of a liquid cytosol and organelles.
The vascularized internal portion of the endometrium in a pregnant uterus; the maternal portion of the placenta.
Act of eliminating undigested waste from the digestive tract.
Act of swallowing.
Change in structure of a protein, such as an enzyme, so that it can no longer function.
Neuron fiber that conducts impulses toward the cell body.
cell Phagocytic white blood cell active in the immune system as an antigen-presenting cell (APC).
Reduction of the membrane potential (charge) resulting from the entry of cations or the exit of anions.
True skin; deeper part of the skin.
Dome-shaped muscle under the lungs that flattens during inhalation; a separating membrane or structure.
Shaft of a long bone.
Freely movable joint; synovial joint.
Relaxation; adj., diastolic (di-as-TOL-ik).
Region of the brain between the cerebral hemispheres and the midbrain; contains the thalamus, hypothalamus, and pituitary gland.
Movement of solutes from a region where they are in higher concentration to a region where they are in lower concentration.
Process of breaking down food into absorbable particles.
Genetic material of the cell; makes up the chromosomes in the cell’s nucleus.
Referring to an allele of a gene that is always expressed in the phenotype if present.
First portion of the small intestine.
Referring to sweat glands that regulate body temperature and vent sweat directly to the surface of the skin through a pore.
Instrument to study the heart by means of ultrasound; the record produced is an echocardiogram.
Muscle or gland that responds to a signal; effector organ.
Carrying away from a given point, such as a motor neuron that carries nerve impulses away from the central nervous system.
Capacity of a structure to return to its original shape after being stretched.
(ECG, EKG) Instrument to study the heart’s electric activity; record made is an electrocardiogram.
(EEG) Instrument used to study the brain’s electric activity; record made is an electroencephalogram.
Compound that separates into ions in solution; substance that conducts an electric current in solution.
Negatively charged particle located in an energy level outside an atom’s nucleus.
One of the substances from which all matter is made; substance that cannot be decomposed into a simpler substance.
Developing offspring during the first eight weeks of gestation.
To break up fats into small particles; n., emulsification.
Membrane that lines the heart’s chambers and covers the valves.
Referring to a gland that secretes into the bloodstream.
System composed of glands that secrete hormones.
Movement of large amounts of material into a cell using vesicles (e.g., phagocytosis and pinocytosis).
Inner layer of the uterus.
Thin membrane that lines a bone marrow cavity.
Epithelium that lines the heart, blood vessels, and lymphatic vessels.
A protein that accelerates a specific chemical reaction.
Granular white blood cell that shows beadlike, bright pink cytoplasmic granules when stained with acid stain.
Membrane that forms the heart wall’s outermost layer and is continuous with the lining of the fibrous pericardium; visceral pericardium.
Outermost layer of the skin.
Leaf-shaped cartilage that covers the larynx during swallowing.
End of a long bone; adj., epiphyseal (ep-ih-FIZ-e-al).
One of the four main types of tissues; forms glands, covers surfaces, and lines cavities; adj., epithelial.
Red blood cell.
Muscular tube that carries food from the throat to the stomach.
Group of female sex hormones that promotes development of the ovarian follicle and the uterine lining and maintains secondary sex characteristics; the main estrogen is estradiol.
In cells, the ability to transmit an electric current along the plasma membrane.
Removal and elimination of metabolic waste products from the blood.
Referring to a gland that secretes through a duct.
Movement of large amounts of material out of the cell using vesicles.
Outside the cell.
Limb.
Band or sheet of fibrous connective tissue.
Small bundle, as of muscle cells or nerve cell fibers.
Union of an ovum and a spermatozoon.
Developing offspring from the start of the ninth week of gestation until birth.
Abnormally high body temperature involving an increased temperature set point.
Blood protein that forms a blood clot.
Cell that produces protein fibers and other components of the matrix in connective tissue.
Movement of material through a semipermeable membrane down a pressure gradient.
Hormone produced by the anterior pituitary that stimulates development of ova in the ovary and spermatozoa in the testes.
Membranous area in the infant skull where bone has not yet formed; also spelled fontanelle; “soft spot.”
Muscular sac on the inferior surface of the liver that stores bile.
Gut-associated lymphoid tissue.
Reproductive cell; ovum or spermatozoon.
Protein fraction in the blood plasma that contains antibodies.
Collection of nerve cell bodies located outside the central nervous system.
Hereditary factor; portion of the DNA on a chromosome encoding a specific protein.
Pertaining to the genes or heredity.
Genetic makeup of an organism.
Period of development from conception to birth.
filtrate Fluid and dissolved materials that leave the blood and enter the kidney tubule.
Cluster of capillaries surrounded by the kidney tubule’s glomerular capsule.
Simple sugar; main energy source for the cells; dextrose.
Compound built from glucose molecules that is stored for energy in the liver and muscles.
First, anaerobic phase of glucose’s metabolic breakdown for energy; converts glucose into pyruvate.
Sense of taste; adj., gustatory.
Raised area of the cerebral cortex; pl., gyri (JI-ri).
Sheath that encloses a hair.
(Hct) Volume percentage of red blood cells in whole blood; packed cell volume.
Pertaining to blood cell formation.
(Hb) Iron-containing protein in red blood cells that binds oxygen.
Rupture of red blood cells; v., hemolyze (HE-mo-lize).
Stoppage of bleeding.
Transmission of characteristics from parent to offspring by means of the genes.
Having unmatched alleles for a given trait; hybrid.
Study of tissues.
State of balance within the body; maintenance of body conditions within set limits.
Having identical alleles in a given gene pair.
Chemical messenger secreted by a tissue that has specific regulatory effects on certain other cells.
(hCG) Hormone produced by embryonic cells soon after implantation that maintains the corpus luteum and is diagnostic of pregnancy.
Splitting of large molecules by the addition of water, as in digestion.
Increased level of carbon dioxide in the blood.
Describing a solution that is more concentrated than the fluids within a cell.
Region of the brain that controls the pituitary; control center for numerous homeostatic negative feedback loops and for the autonomic nervous system.
Describing a solution that is less concentrated than are the fluids within a cell.
Lower than normal level of oxygen in the tissues.
Power of an individual to resist or overcome the effects of a disease or other harmful agent.
Use of a vaccine to produce immunity; vaccination.
(Ig) Substance produced in response to a specific antigen; immunoglobulin.
Embedding of a fertilized ovum into the uterine lining.
Response of tissues to injury or infection; characterized by heat, redness, swelling, and pain.
Intake of food.
Muscle attachment connected to a movable part.
The skin and all its associated structures.
(IFN) Group of substances released from virus-infected cells that prevent spread of infection to other cells; also nonspecifically boosts the immune system.
Substance released by a T cell, macrophage, or endothelial cell that regulates other immune system cells.
Nerve cell that transmits impulses within the central nervous system or enteric (gastrointestinal) nervous system.
Stage in a cell’s life between one mitosis and the next when the cell is not dividing.
Between; pertaining to an organ’s spaces or structures between active tissues; also refers to the fluid between cells.
Organ of the digestive tract between the stomach and the anus, consisting of the small and large intestine.
Within a cell.
Atom or molecule with an electrical charge; anion or cation.
Circular colored region of the eye around the pupil.
Describing a solution that has the same concentration as the fluid within a cell.
Form of an element that has the same atomic number as another form of that element but a different atomic weight; isotopes differ in their numbers of neutrons.
Area of junction between two or more bones; articulation.
Protein that thickens and protects the skin; makes up hair and nails.
Organ of excretion, hormone synthesis, and blood pressure regulation.
(kcal) Measure of the energy content of food; technically, the amount of heat needed to raise l kg of water 1°C; calorie (C).
Sense of body movement.
apparatus Lacrimal (tear) gland and its associated ducts.
Secretion of milk.
Lymphatic capillary that drains digested fats from the villi of the small intestine.
Structure between the pharynx and trachea that contains the vocal cords; voice box.
Biconvex structure of the eye that changes in thickness to accommodate near and far vision; crystalline lens.
White blood cell.
system Area between the brain’s cerebrum and diencephalon that is involved in emotional states, memory, and behavior.
Type of organic compound, one example of which is a fat.
Large organ inferior to the diaphragm in the superior right abdomen; has many functions, including bile secretion, detoxification, storage, and interconversion of nutrients.
Organ of respiration.
hormone (LH) Hormone produced by the anterior pituitary that induces ovulation and formation of the corpus luteum in females; in males, it stimulates cells in the testes to produce testosterone.
Fluid in the lymphatic system.
Mass of lymphoid tissue along the path of a lymphatic vessel that filters lymph and harbors white blood cells active in immunity.
One of two large vessels draining lymph from the lymphatic system into the venous system.
Agranular white blood cell that functions in acquired immunity.
Large phagocytic cell that develops from a monocyte; presents antigen to other leukocytes in immune response.

Spot; flat, discolored spot on the skin, such as a freckle or measles. Area of the retina that contains the point of sharpest vision; equilibrium receptor in the vestibule of the inner ear. Also macule.
Mucosal-associated lymphoid tissue; tissue in the mucous membranes that helps fight infection.
Any soft, gelatinous material resembling bone marrow.
White blood cell related to a basophil that is present in tissues; active in inflammatory and allergic reactions.
Act of chewing.
The acellular background material in a tissue; the intercellular material.
Region between the lungs and the organs and vessels it contains.
Part of the brain stem that connects the brain to the spinal cord.
Very large bone marrow cell that gives rise to blood platelets.
Process of cell division that halves the chromosome number in the formation of the gametes.
Dark pigment found in the skin, hair, parts of the eye, and certain parts of the brain.
Cell that produces melanin.
Thin sheet of tissue; lipid bilayer surrounding a cell or an organelle.
Difference in electric charge on either side of a plasma membrane; transmembrane potential.
Three layers of fibrous membranes that cover the brain and spinal cord.
Time during which menstruation ceases.
Monthly flow of blood from the female reproductive tract.
Period of menstrual flow.
Connective tissue membrane that attaches the small intestine to the dorsal abdominal wall.
Rate at which energy is released from nutrients in the cells.
All the physical and chemical processes by which an organism is maintained.
(mcm) 1/1,000th of a millimeter; an instrument for measuring through a microscope (pronounced mi-KROM-eh-ter).

Magnifying instrument used to examine cells and other structures not visible with the naked eye; examples are the compound light microscope, transmission electron microscope (TEM), and scanning electron microscope (SEM).
Act of urination; voiding of the urinary bladder.
Upper portion of the brain stem.
Inorganic substance; in the diet, an element needed in small amounts for health.
Cellular organelles that manufacture ATP with the energy released from the oxidation of nutrients; sing., mitochondrion.
Type of cell division that produces two daughter cells exactly like the parent cell.
Particle formed by covalent bonding of two or more atoms; smallest subunit of a compound.
Phagocytic agranular white blood cell that differentiates into a macrophage.
Describing structures or activities involved in transmitting impulses away from the central nervous system; efferent.
Group consisting of a single neuron and all the muscle fibers it stimulates.
Epithelial membrane that produces mucus; mucous membrane.
Thick protective fluid secreted by mucous membranes and glands; adj., mucous.
Abnormal heart sound.
Change in a gene or a chromosome.
Middle layer of the heart wall; heart muscle.
Compound that stores oxygen in muscle cells.
One of the two contractile proteins in muscle cells, the other being actin.
cell Type of lymphocyte that can nonspecifically destroy abnormal cells.
Self-regulating system in which the result of an action reverses that action; a method for keeping body conditions within a normal range and maintaining homeostasis.
Microscopic functional unit of the kidney; consists of the glomerulus and the renal tubule.
Bundle of neuron fibers outside the central nervous system.
Electric charge that spreads along the membrane of a neuron; action potential.
Supporting and protective cells of the nervous system; glial cells.
Point at which a neuron’s axon contacts a muscle cell.
Conducting cell of the nervous system.
Chemical released from the ending of an axon that enables a nerve impulse to cross a chemical synapse.
Noncharged particle in an atom’s nucleus.
Phagocytic granular white blood cell; polymorph; poly; PMN; seg.
Neurotransmitter similar in composition and action to the hormone epinephrine; noradrenaline.
Building block of DNA and RNA; one is also a component of ATP.
Largest cellular organelle, containing the DNA, which directs all cell activities; group of neurons in the central nervous system; in chemistry, the central part of an atom.
Branch of medicine that is concerned with the care of women during pregnancy, childbirth, and the six weeks after childbirth.
Sense of smell; adj., olfactory.
Body part containing two or more tissues functioning together for specific purposes.
Specialized subdivision within a cell.
Source; beginning; muscle attachment connected to a nonmoving part.
Term that refers to the solute concentration of a solution; osmotic concentration.
Passage of water through a semipermeable membrane from the region of lower solute concentration to the region of higher solute concentration.
One of three small bones of the middle ear: malleus, incus, or stapes.
Bone-forming cell.
Cell that breaks down bone.
Mature bone cell; maintains bone but does not produce new bone tissue.
Subunit of compact bone, consisting of concentric rings of bone tissue around a central channel; haversian system.
Cluster of cells containing an ovum. A follicle can mature during a menstrual cycle and release its ovum.
Female reproductive organ; produces ova and female sex steroids.
Release of an ovum from a mature ovarian follicle (graafian follicle).
Female reproductive cell or gamete; pl., ova.
Chemical breakdown of nutrients for energy usually using oxygen.
Hormone from the posterior pituitary that causes uterine contraction and milk ejection (“letdown”) from the breasts.
Group of cells or artificial device that sets activity rate; in the heart, the sinoatrial (SA) node that normally initiates contractions.
Large, elongated gland behind the stomach; produces digestive enzymes and hormones (e.g., insulin, glucagon).
Craniosacral division of the autonomic nervous system; generally reverses the fight or flight (stress) response.
Pertaining to the wall of a space or cavity.
Childbirth; labor.
Fibrous sac lined with serous membrane that encloses the heart.
Connective tissue membrane covering a bone.
Wavelike movements in the wall of an organ or duct that propel its contents forward.
Serous membrane that lines the abdominal cavity and forms the outer layer of the abdominal organs; forms supporting ligaments for some organs.
Symbol indicating hydrogen ion (H+) concentration; lower numbers indicate a higher H+ concentration and higher acidity.
Engulfing of large particles through the plasma membrane.
Throat; passageway between the mouth and esophagus.
All the characteristics of an organism that can be seen or tested for.
Nerve that activates the diaphragm.
Study of the function of living organisms.
gland Endocrine gland located under and controlled by the hypothalamus; releases hormones that control other glands; hypophysis.
Structure that nourishes and maintains the developing fetus during pregnancy.
Liquid portion of the blood.
Cell derived from a B cell that produces antibodies.
Outer covering of a cell; regulates what enters and leaves the cell; cell membrane.
Cell fragment that forms a plug to stop bleeding and acts in blood clotting; thrombocyte.
Serous membrane that lines the chest cavity and covers the lungs.
Network of vessels or nerves.
Area of the brain between the midbrain and medulla; connects the cerebellum with the rest of the central nervous system.
Distal to the synaptic cleft.
Proximal to the synaptic cleft.
The main muscle that produces a given movement.
Offspring, descendent.
Hormone produced by the corpus luteum and placenta; maintains the uterine lining for pregnancy.
Sensory receptor that aids in judging body position and changes in position; located in muscles, tendons, and joints.
Any of a group of hormones produced by many cells that usually act on neighboring cells; these hormones are involved in pain and inflammation, as well as many other functions.
Organic compound made of amino acids; found as structural materials and metabolically active compounds, such as enzymes, some hormones, pigments, antibodies, and others.
Positively charged particle in an atom’s nucleus. May also refer to the hydrogen ion (H+), which consists of a single proton.
Exchange of air between the atmosphere and the alveoli of the lungs.
Wave of increased pressure in the vessels produced by heart contraction.
Pertaining to isotopes that fall apart easily, giving off radiation.

Specialized cell or ending of a sensory neuron that can be excited by a stimulus. Protein in the plasma membrane or other part of a cell that binds a chemical signal (e.g., hormone, neurotransmitter) resulting in a change in cellular activity.
Referring to an allele that is not expressed in the phenotype if a dominant allele for the same trait is present.
Simple, rapid, automatic response to a specific stimulus.
Bending of light rays as they pass from one medium to another of a different density.
Enzyme released from the kidney’s juxtaglomerular apparatus that indirectly increases blood pressure by activating angiotensin.
A change in the membrane potential that brings it closer to the resting value.
Loss of substance from a solid tissue, such as bone or a tooth, and return of the components to the blood.
Process by which oxygen is obtained from the environment and delivered to the cells as carbon dioxide is removed from the tissues and released to the environment.
formation Network in the limbic system that governs wakefulness and sleep.
Innermost layer of the eye; contains light-sensitive cells (rods and cones).
Small body in the cell’s cytoplasm that is a site of protein manufacture.
Substance needed for protein manufacture in the cell.
Secretion of the salivary glands; moistens food and contains an enzyme that digests starch.
Compound formed by reaction between an acid and a base (e.g., NaCl, table salt).
conduction Transmission of an electric impulse from node to node along a myelinated fiber; faster than continuous conduction along the entire membrane.
Contracting subunit of skeletal muscle.
Outermost layer of the eye; made of tough connective tissue; “white” of the eye.
Pertaining to sebum, an oily substance secreted by skin glands.
Oily secretion that lubricates the skin; adj., sebaceous (se-BA-shus).
Alternating contraction and relaxation of the circular muscle in the small intestine’s wall that mix its contents with digestive juices and move them through the organ.
Mixture of sperm cells and secretions from several glands of the male reproductive tract.
One of three curved channels of the inner ear where receptors for rotational equilibrium are located.
Describing cells or activities involved in transmitting impulses toward the central nervous system; afferent.
Gradual loss of sensation when sensory receptors are exposed to continuous stimulation.
Part of the nervous system that detects a stimulus.
Dividing wall, as between the chambers of the heart or the nasal cavities.
Serous membrane; epithelial membrane that secretes a thin, watery fluid.
Liquid portion of blood without clotting factors; thin, watery fluid; adj., serous (SE-rus).
Referring to a gene carried on a sex chromosome, usually the X chromosome.
Enlarged capillary that serves as a blood channel.
Bony framework of the body; adj., skeletal.
Substance that is dissolved in another substance (the solvent).
Homogeneous mixture of one substance dissolved in another; the components in a mixture are evenly distributed and cannot be distinguished from each other.
Substance in which another substance (the solute) is dissolved.
nervous system Division of the nervous system that controls voluntary activities and stimulates skeletal muscle.
Male reproductive cell or gamete; pl., spermatozoa; sperm cell.
Muscular ring that regulates the size of an opening.
Device used to measure blood pressure; blood pressure apparatus or cuff.
organ Receptor for hearing located in the cochlea of the internal ear; organ of Corti.
Instrument for recording lung volumes; tracing obtained is a spirogram.
Lymphoid organ in the upper left region of the abdomen.
Cell that has the potential to divide and produce different types of cells.
Category of lipids that includes the hormones of the sex glands and the adrenal cortex.
Organ of the digestive tract that stores food, mixes it with digestive juices, and moves it into the small intestine.
Deepest layer of the epidermis; layer that produces new epidermal cells; stratum germinativum.
layer Under the skin.
Substance on which an enzyme works.
gland Producing sweat; referring to the sweat glands.
Shallow groove as between convolutions of the cerebral cortex; pl., sulci (SUL-si).
Substance in the alveoli that prevents their collapse by reducing surface tension of the fluid lining them.
Heterogeneous mixture that will separate unless shaken.
Thoracolumbar division of the autonomic nervous system; stimulates a fight or flight (stress) response.
Junction between two neurons or between a neuron and an effector.
Immovable joint.
Substance or structure that enhances the work of another. A muscle that works with a prime mover to produce a given movement.
Pertaining to a thick, lubricating fluid found in joints, bursae, and tendon sheaths; pertaining to a freely movable (diarthrotic) joint.
Group of organs functioning together for the same general purposes.
Contraction; adj., systolic (sis-TOL-ik).
Lymphocyte active in immunity that matures in the thymus gland; may destroy foreign cells directly or help in or regulate the immune response; T lymphocyte.
Heart rate more than 100 beats per minute in an adult.
Tissue that is capable of responding to a specific hormone.
Cord of regular dense connective tissue that attaches a muscle to a bone.
Male reproductive gland; pl., testes (TES-teze).
Male sex hormone produced in the testes; promotes sperm cell development and maintains secondary sex characteristics.
Region of the brain located in the diencephalon; chief relay center for sensory impulses traveling to the cerebral cortex.
Clotting factor in the blood needed to convert fibrinogen to fibrin.
Lymphoid organ in the upper portion of the chest; site of T-cell development.
Group of similar cells that performs a specialized function.
Mass of lymphoid tissue in the region of the pharynx.
Partially contracted state of muscle; also, tone.
Poison.
Altered toxin used to produce active immunity.
Tube that extends from the larynx to the bronchi; windpipe.
Bundle of neuron fibers within the central nervous system.
Characteristic.
Introduction of blood or blood components directly into the bloodstream of a recipient.
Protein that works with troponin to regulate contraction in skeletal muscle.
Protein that works with tropomyosin to regulate contraction in skeletal muscle.
Return of substances in the glomerular filtrate to the circulation through the renal tubule.
membrane Membrane between the external and middle ear that transmits sound waves to the bones of the middle ear; eardrum.
cord Structure that connects the fetus with the placenta; contains vessels that carry blood between the fetus and placenta.
Nitrogenous waste product excreted in the urine; end product of protein metabolism.
Tube that carries urine from the kidney to the urinary bladder.
Tube that carries urine from the urinary bladder to the outside of the body.
bladder Hollow organ that stores urine until it is eliminated.
Liquid waste excreted by the kidneys.
Muscular, pear-shaped organ in the female pelvis within which the fetus develops during pregnancy; adj., uterine.
Substance used to produce active immunity; usually, a suspension of attenuated or killed pathogens or some component of a pathogen given by inoculation to prevent a specific disease.
Combining power of an atom; number of electrons lost, gained, or shared by atoms of an element in chemical reactions.
Structure that prevents fluid from flowing backward, as in the heart, veins, and lymphatic vessels.
Decrease in a blood vessel’s lumen diameter.
Increase in a blood vessel’s lumen diameter.
Pertaining to dilation or constriction of blood vessels.
Vessel that carries blood toward the heart.
Large vein that carries blood into the heart’s right atrium; superior vena cava or inferior vena cava.
Large channel that drains blood low in oxygen.
Cavity or chamber. One of the heart’s two lower chambers. One of the brain’s four chambers in which cerebrospinal fluid is produced; adj., ventricular (ven-TRIK-u-lar).
Vessel between a capillary and a vein.
Any space at the entrance to a canal or organ; in the inner ear, area that contains some receptors for the sense of equilibrium.
Small finger-like projections from the surface of a membrane; projections in the lining of the small intestine through which digested food is absorbed; sing., villus.
Organs in the ventral body cavities, especially the abdominal organs; adj., visceral.
Organic compound needed in small amounts for health.
body Soft, jelly-like substance that fills the eyeball and holds the shape of the eye; vitreous humor.
Fertilized ovum; cell formed by the union of a sperm and an egg.
